what what do we mean by microservices it's a bit of a definitely a buzzword
and so it's good to kind of step back and look at that more so you know in the course of my
programming career we've moved from monolithic applications where we had one big server or a few big servers running
really big apps everything was all kind of in one big build and we've broken that apart into microservices and
there's a few reasons there's it re reasons and business reasons so the it
reasons are definitely you get a lot of flexibility by breaking an application
apart into one big thing that you deploy as one big unit if instead you can break that down into
individual smaller components you've got flexibility as you deploy them
one of the nice things about that flexibility is then you can move from uh
from hard you know from big iron servers to virtual machines and then you can
actually go from there further to containerized applications so with a vm
you're getting some benefit to abstracting from the hardware but you're still kind of you're still running the
whole operating system and you're only really virtualizing the machine what if we could break that down further
and virtualize at the application level so uh when we do that
we're we're virtualizing away the operating system and now we're down to just scaling out by
by our units by our application as a unit and of course with that and running on
docker is kind of the most common although there are some others out there we get a lot of flexibility over what we
can do so for instance if we're running with multiple uh multiple instances on one machine and
it's underutilized we can swap them around and you know d uh shut down one of the vms
etc so that's all great from a hardware perspective but
that's not really the only reason why microservices are being used and
you know what i've been learning over time is really one of the main impacts is the business agility and what that
means is instead of waiting for one big build when everything's ready to go we can ship a service as soon as it's ready
and that also means that you can get your bug fixes and features out much more quickly so you can you know be
deploying multiple times a day instead of waiting to make sure everything's tested and works together
you can also break things down at the team level so you can
you can make some smarter decisions with that one team might prefer to work with you know net sql server etc another may
want to use you know f sharp and postgres and another or a document database or go or whatever right
so if you're if you're working at the application level that it lets each team and project decide what's best for them
and you can also focus on business capabilities for a team so for instance a team or a service may be completely
focused on ordering and they can really become experts in that area
and so you know brendan burns co-founder of kubernetes has sum this up well that
it's microservices are really about scaling at the team level
